text.0:
- A christian introduced Arabic inscription to Naira notes
- Former President Goodluck Jonathan removed Arabic from the Naira
- The numerical system was invented by a Muslim mathematician

Are these claims by MURIC true? Here are the facts: https://t.co/Jxvp1jU54n #DubawaChecks
text.1: The #COVID19 pandemic marked the start of a new wave of fake news. Dubawa took on the challenge and became a first responder in tackling the COVID-19 infodemic. Watch this documentary to see our Covid-19 fact-checks. Click the link to watch: https://t.co/unxAYGOGS3  #DubawaChecks
text.2: @AbdulMahmud01 Thank you for a fantastic session, and happy birthday!
text.4: @HamzyCODE @dubawaNG I know twitter does employ some fact checking standards to help curb misinformation, but most if this is region biased, and very little co-op with regions like ours and available teams/standards I see as a big issue
text.5:
@dubawaNG Influencers should protect the truth and expose lies always!

Thanks for having me on.
text.6:
And finally, What is your take on social media regulation by the government? @AbdulMahmud01 

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.7: The looting had nothing to do with fake news. The invisible underclass took advantage of a state that was incapable of addressing law and order issues that were at the core of the protests
text.8: The second wave was state sponsored- organised by protest-breakers paid by the government to take over the streets. Having entered the streets and found that there were opportunities to loot, they began their mindless orgies. #DubawaChecks #FactsmatterNG
text.10: Is what I am about to say in flagrant violation of the law? Does it assault moral consciences? So drawing the line is a function of two realities- law and moral
text.11: I think it is important we clarify the #Endsars protests, which came in two waves. The first wave was peaceful and driven by those who were concerned about police brutality #DubawaChecks #FactsmatterNG https://t.co/k8JiOIFZuz
text.12:
@dubawaNG Tech companies need to flag violent posts and possibly create a two-step authenticator before a user can post. 

Something like this has begun on Twitter. @Twitter now asks you if you'll like to read an article before Retweeting.
text.16: Rights are never absolute; they're limited by legal and constitutional  instruments. Drawing the line should be a thing of law and common sense really #DubawaChecks #FactsmatterNG https://t.co/vuFQJTV7aE
text.18:
@dubawaNG Comparing videos, photos and other information shared on the #endsars protests in Nigeria, my inclinations are:

1. Armed security agents were at the toll gate to quell the protests. 
2. Shoots were fired leading to injuries and fatalities. 
3. Men of the Nigeria Police Force...
text.19: @wemimospot @NigeriainfoFM Great responses. Thank you so much for your time!
text.20:
@dubawaNG @NigeriainfoFM A lot of Nigerians are not on social media. They consume news from Radio, TV and newspapers. 

Without these media houses covering the #endsars protests, a lot of Nigerians didn't understand the real intent of the protests. This fuelled some animosity.
text.21:
@dubawaNG As a journalist, my media house @NigeriainfoFM covered the #endsars protests from the very beginning.

A lot of media houses at the early stage of the protests however appeared to shy away for fear of sanctions. This created a great vacuum that was filled with misinformation.
text.22:
Welcome our third and final panelist @AbdulMahmud01 

How do we draw that line between what we see as 'my right to say what I want ' and the question of basically becoming the source of conspiracy theories and falsehoods?

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG https://t.co/QTs2GzLjRD
text.23:
It’s believed that the #EndSARS protest was not adequately covered by a large section of the Nigerian media; did this misstep influence the deluge of misinformation experienced during the protest? @wemimospot

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.24:
@dubawaNG There are also tools for journalists and all internet users to verify photos before sharing.

Google Reverse Image and Tin eye are great tools for verifying pictures. You'll see every possible place and time the same picture has been shared and under what context.
text.25: @dubawaNG If you're the source of the video, while recording, be sure to mention the date, time, and location. If possible, a very brief description of the incident to provide context.
text.26:
@dubawaNG Yes there are. 

Before you repost a video, be sure to check the environment in the video/picture. Lagos buses are yellow. If the information is said to have happened in Lagos, can you sight anything that looks like Lagos?
text.27:
Based on fact-checking we’re sure you must have done, what are you leaning towards on the #LekkiMassacre? @wemimospot

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.28:
With the Facebook and Instagram missteps experienced during the #EndSARS protest, how do you think tech companies can better combate online misinformation? @wemimospot

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.29:
@dubawaNG When you double check, the chance of being wrong is greatly reduced. 

#FactsMatterNG #Dubawachecks
text.30:
@dubawaNG 1. the source of the information. Is it a parody account? Also verify with authentic news sites.
2. Read the article posted. Flag grammatical errors 
3. Language. What languages are being spoken in the video? English? French?
4. Date stamp: is there a date stamp on the document?
text.31: @dubawaNG Social media is a great place for sharing information. It also, however is a place with convincingly presented misinformation.  Sometimes, the misinformation is unknowingly shared. To check accuracy, pay attention to:
text.33: @dubawaNG .... fact-checkers or refine their algorithms to prevent the spread of fake news. On the users’ end, we can do more to educate them on how to spot this fake news. #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG 3/3
text.34: @dubawaNG I see solid points on both sides. Social media platforms can certainly do better in flagging frequently reported content as fake news before they get out of hand. These companies are big enough to employ the services of designated .... 2/3 #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.35: @dubawaNG You could make two arguments here: one that the content we see on our feeds are a result of what we interact with the most (echo chamber) or that social media companies are not doing enough to filter what users end up seeing. 1/3 #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.36: @dubawaNG Once you have the reach, it goes beyond personal gains or ideals. One wrong tweet could lead to loss of lives and properties. We must exercise restraint and caution and always put country first above interests. 2/2 #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.37: @dubawaNG Influencers can combat misinformation by doing some fact-checking before sharing anything with their audience. As people with substantial social media followers, we have the responsibility to be mindful of what we engage with and promote. 1/2 #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.38: @HamzyCODE Excellent points! Thank you so much for your time @HamzyCODE
text.39:
Welcome our second panelist: @wemimospot

What is the easiest and fastest way for social media users to fact-check information before sharing?

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG https://t.co/APjR127ZAO
text.40:
Bearing in mind that the things we share online can spread like wildfire and a small share can have big consequences; what roles do you think social media influencers can play in combating misinformation? @HamzyCODE

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.41:
Going by the #endsars experience, it’s been said that social media algorithms may not be doing a good job at identifying what’s fake and what isn’t. What is your take on this? @HamzyCODE 

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.42: @dubawaNG We must first educate users on ways to fact check. Social media platforms can provide resources on fact-checking and be more proactive about flagging of fake news. 2/2 #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG
text.43: @dubawaNG I think it is more of a question of whether the average social media user knows how to fact-check. Information on social media is often validated by the number of engagements (Retweets, shares and likes). #DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG  1/2
text.44: @dubawaNG 3/3 This was especially significant as more youth get their news via online sources than traditional media. This helped #EndSARs organisers reach a larger audience. #FactsMatterNG #DubawaChecks
text.45: @dubawaNG ... as the online trend grew stronger and more influencers began to speak up about police brutality. #EndSARs Protest meeting points, resources and updates were often communicated online. 2/3 #FactsMatterNG #DubawaChecks
text.46: @dubawaNG Without a doubt, the duration, attendance and coverage of the peaceful #EndSars protests were heavily influenced by social media. Many young people were inspired to participate in the movement 1/3 #FactsMatterNG #DubawaChecks
text.48:
Many youths relied on social media as their primary source of news during the #endsars protest; does this have any role to play in the outcome of the protest? 

@HamzyCODE  #FactsMatterNG
text.49: @dubawaNG .... would prevent a soldier from shooting you. Misinformation like this is not only improbable but could cost us lives. While a lot of the agitation was stirred by genuine anger caused by the incidence of police brutality, misinformation had a role to play in fanning the flames.
text.50: @dubawaNG In a time when many citizens came online to share stories of loss and empathetic with others, some shared pure fabrications whether knowingly or unknowingly. One instance of the dangers of fake news is the claim that carrying the Nigerian flag #FactsMatterNG #DubawaChecks
text.51: @dubawaNG The phenomenon of the internet offers two sides of a coin: information and misinformation. It is a vacuum where news of all kinds can thrive and this was no different at the peak of the recent #EndSARS protests. During the protests, tensions and emotions were high.
text.52:
Our first question goes to our first panelists @HamzyCODE: What role do you think misinformation played in the #EndSARS protest? 

#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG https://t.co/nMRHOUvtsO
text.53: Welcome to our TweetChat in collaboration with @ICFJ where we discuss #EndSARS and misinformation in Nigeria’s social media space. Please don’t forget to use #DubawaChecks and #FactsMatterNG to contribute and send in your questions. Let’s Begin! https://t.co/8PrYTrs4dP
text.54:
Today's the day! Join us on Twitter by 12pm today alongside @HamzyCODE, @wemimospot and @AbdulMahmud01 as we discuss the #EndSARS protest and misinformation in Nigeria’s social media space, in collaboration with @ICFJKnight! See you in 1 hour!
 
#DubawaChecks #FactsMatterNG. https://t.co/0162A3C4Ze
text.55: A Facebook user posted a picture with the claim that there is an ongoing protest in Algeria demanding all political officials vacate office before elections, comparing it to the #EndSARS protests. However, the claim is misleading. Read here: https://t.co/sXa7fRDMfy  #DubawaChecks
text.56: Experts  across media, academia, civil society and policymaking field have identified the factors responsible for the spread of ‘fake news’ during the #EndSARS protest in Nigeria. Read here: https://t.co/WJk7Dv5PYq #DubawaChecks
